awd_titl_txt: RI: Small: Collaborative Research: RUI: Scalable Decentralized Planning in Open Multiagent Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Automated planning is about finding a sequence of actions that is anticipated to successfully complete the task at hand or maximize earned rewards. Planning becomes difficult when the outcomes of actions are uncertain. It is further complicated in the presence of other agents whose actions also affect the environment and reward outcomes. While both these challenges have received much attention from researchers, real-world contexts often exhibit another property -- that of agent and task openness. Agent openness comes about when agents exit the environment, resume, or new agents enter, and task openness occurs when the tasks that agents must complete change with new tasks appearing and some disappearing.  Such openness complicates the planning process as agents now need to optimally consider, for example, the possibilities of existing teammates leaving the environment or a successfully rewarding task disappearing from the environment.  The research is systematically generalizing automated planning to consider these new and practical challenges while still keeping the methods computationally feasible. This research involves investigators at Oberlin College (a primarily undergraduate institution), Universities of Nebraska and Georgia collaborating closely to develop methods for planning in open multi-agent systems and demonstrating them in domains such as wildfire suppression, dynamic ridesharing, and others that exhibit openness. The principal investigators are using the outcomes of this research to inform their classroom instructions, and artificial intelligence camps for elementary and middle school students are planned at Oberlin.

The technical approach involves gaining a fundamental understanding of the impact of agent and task openness on the environment, and utilizing this understanding to develop and learn stochastic models that represent the openness. These models are being used to build new algorithms for tractable agent-level planning in such contexts. The methods will exploit system-level properties such as agent anonymity and statistical population sampling that allows modeling large populations from small samples, which has been successful in the social sciences to make the approaches scalable to many agents. This research is advancing our understanding of how intelligent agents should perform scalable, decentralized planning in complex environments, and developing a framework--with empirical results and insights--that could lead to more robust intelligence for personal assistant agents for human-agent interactions, robots, and autonomous vehicles, where the agents reason about challenging environmental dynamics as the actors and their tasks change over time.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Multiagent systems composed of interacting autonomous agents are popular approaches for enabling complex AI decision-making when information is incomplete and future outcomes are uncertain.  Many real-world environments -- such as robotic wildfire suppression, cybersecurity defense, and dynamic ridesharing -- are especially challenging for multiagent decision-making because these environments represent open agent systems where both the sets of agents acting to accomplish goals and the sets of tasks they aim to complete change over time in unpredictable ways.  For example, robot firefighters frequently run out of limited suppressant resources and must disengage from ongoing collaborations to recharge, while other robots take damage and suffer reduced operability.  New tasks in the form of new fires to be extinguished appear dynamically and unexpectedly, prompting agents to reconsider their priorities.  As a result, existing plans and learned knowledge quickly become outdated, greatly complicating the reasoning of multiagent systems and hence their ability to operate effectively and efficiently in real-world environments.

This project developed novel methods of planning that successfully address the additional complexities of reasoning in open agent systems.  Our primary contributions include the following.  We developed a scalable decision process model that appropriately estimates and predicts the presence of other agents as they come and go from the open environment, then plans in real-time how to operate cooperatively, competitively, or in a self-interested manner (depending on the application).  Taking inspiration from public polling within the social sciences, our methods model the behaviors of a few peers and extrapolate to the whole multiagent system, enabling reasoning to scale to many-agent environments with at least an order-of-magnitude more agents than prior solutions.  Our theoretical analysis also establishes bounded approximation errors for our method.  We also developed a communicative framework whereby agents individually decide how and when to exchange information about their (often otherwise unobservable) presence in open agent systems that is coupled with a real-time (fully online) planning algorithm in order to reduce the uncertainty caused by agent openness and promote effective decision-making.    Finally, we produced a suite of customizable benchmark problems spanning multiple real-world applications of open agent systems for the evaluation of stochastic process models and planning algorithms (as well as multiagent learning).  Our contributions also provided broader impacts through (1) strengthening connections between modeling diverse decision makers in the social sciences and AI, (2) a publication surveying the current state of research in open agent systems and highlighting key areas of future work to continue advancing this area, (3) novel educational materials introducing real-world complexities of multiagent decision making caused by open agent systems, (4) collaboration across multiple institutions, and (5) the training of several graduate students who are now employed in the AI workforce.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2024
Modified by: Adam D Eck
